Robert Soane

Hello and welcome to my site. I am a postgraduate student at the University of Nottingham, currently studying for an MSc in Computer Science.

I post some projects from my course, (as well as some I do on the side for fun!) on this site. Some of the more recent projects are listed below, and everything I've posted can be found on the Projects page. A few I found particularly interesting were:

  • Pyfighter - A group project as part of my MSc (ranked second of all games submitted and graded distinction - 89%).
  • A Brief History of Encryption - A report on cyber security as part of my MSc
  • Othello - An Othello engine made in pygame.
  • Simulations to Demonstrate Mathematics - One of my projects for my BSc in Mathematics. Most interesting was programming a simulation of a double pendulum in JavaScript.

Recent Projects

Pyfighter

Pyfighter is an 8-bit side scrolling, infinite level platform game, produced in python using PyGame as part on an MSc by R. Soane, R. Danevicius, and S. Mistry. Inspired by super street fighter, super smash bros and Mario, they created a customisable and addictive game that gets progressively harder.

Posted by Robert on December 18, 2020 · 5 mins read

Othello (GUI)

This side project was to produce a fully functional GUI Othello engine. This was initially set as a challenge during an MSc tutorial to produce an Othello engine using minimax. I built a working engine (initially in the command line) and have since produced a GUI for it.

Posted by Robert on December 02, 2020 · 3 mins read

A Brief History of Encryption

As an assignment for one of my MSc modules I had to produce a report on cyber security. I chose to focus on encryption methods. Graded Distinction.

Posted by Robert on October 29, 2020 · 28 mins read

Klotksi Problem

A recursive solution to the Klotski problem written in python. Searches all possible moves (which don't result in a repeat) and finds a solution to the problem. Takes approx 2:40 to find first solution on my pc.

Posted by Robert on October 28, 2020 · 1 min read
